column4: Hi there! I rebooted a machine yesterday and I suddently cannot login anymore. The ssh session freezes right after successful authentication.
Is it a netbook?
no, a server.
Did you recently update the kernel?
yes.
Try adding 'nohz=off' to the command-line params to the kernel & see if that fixes the problem.
i cant login via ssh, remember? only thing working is opening a scp connection and then starting a shell from winscp. Its not real ssh shell thoug
i cant use any editors on that shell
you were kind of quick with a possible answer, is that a "known problem" ?

It is with the right combination of hardware and software. Certain motherboards (esp. those in certain netbooks) don't like the advanced power-saving code in the latest kernels. "nohz=off" disables it, at the expense of power savings.
its a root machine that has been running a while now. real server hardware.
the machine is running fine, apart from the login issue. is there a way to verify the issue before addin the kernel parameter?
If it's the login issue alone, it's unlikely to be the issue I'm talking about. I've made a mistake.
If it freezes at authentication, could there be a problem w/ file permissions, domain name resolution. ...?
file permission problems should be visible in the auth.log dont they?
I would say so. Do you have access to auth.log?
yes, as SFTP via ssh2 is working ... strangely
i cant see any problems in auth.log, another strange thing is, the sessions are open and kept alive. "who" shows me that there are even sessions left open from yesterday.
name resolution seems to be working too ...
ans since the "unix like" shell from WinSCP is working, i'd say it is a sshd problem ... just dont know where to look at right now ...
no idea?
